messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: Tell that to my sword blade s that are pre-showa. ... From: nihontochicken To:
messages.messageBody:
Tell that to my sword blade's that are pre-showa.
----- Original Message -----
From: nihontochicken<mailto:rick@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, July 23, 2006 11:21 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp


Yes, many ancestral blades were remounted in gunto koshirae and
carried off to the Pacific War. But they were not stamped with the
Showa cherry blossom. A Showa stamp, also the nearly as common Seki
stamp, indicates the blade is not completely traditionally made. In
some better examples that look very traditional, displaying both hada
and water tempered hamon, the stamp indicates it was made with western
style steel instead of the traditional tamahagane.

NC

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>, "mark sala" <franzkafka19@...> wrote:
>
> Yes this is true. Old mounts removed and new military mounts as
replacements. Reason for this is to make the sword SHOWA. I have
several, well more than several. Mark Happy collecting.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: bobgriffis<mailto:bob.griffis@...>
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com><mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>>

> Showa stamp for use during WWII. What is the truth?

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: Bob, I ve seen several pieces that were nontraditionally made that had hada, interesting hamons, etc.,.  There were some interesting comments in one of Kapp s
messages.messageBody:
Bob,

I've seen several pieces that were nontraditionally made that had hada,
interesting hamons, etc.,. There were some interesting comments in
one of Kapp's books about how some of these were made with wrought iron
from train rails.

One other thing to look for is nie - no nie usually means not
traditionally made.

rkg
(Richard George)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: I m asking because I have a blade which has all the hallmarks of a traditionally made blade--Masame hada, a well defined and unusual hamon, an 8.5 nakago with
messages.messageBody:
I'm asking because I have a blade which has all the hallmarks of a
traditionally made blade--Masame hada, a well defined and unusual hamon,
an 8.5" nakago with taka no ha yasurime and signature. It is longer
than most WWII blades (ha is 26.75"). It also has a Showa cherry
blossom stamp. The polisher said it was a folded blade (19 folds),
confirmed by CAT scan, and was one of the hardest blades to polish he
had come across. Lacking the Showa stamp, they believed its
craftsmanship indicated a pre 1860s blade

Its matching saya is also unusual--it is covered in a tan-colored same
which is 3 skins expertly applied, but the gunto mount looks hacked in
as if retrofitted later.

So, absent the Showa stamp, both blade and saya suggest an ancestoral
blade that was stamped and refitted as gunto for use in WWII. What else
might I look for to authenticate it?

messages.subject: Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, many ancestral blades were remounted in gunto koshirae and carried off to the Pacific War.  But they were not stamped with the Showa cherry blossom.  A
messages.messageBody:
Yes, many ancestral blades were remounted in gunto koshirae and
carried off to the Pacific War. But they were not stamped with the
Showa cherry blossom. A Showa stamp, also the nearly as common Seki
stamp, indicates the blade is not completely traditionally made. In
some better examples that look very traditional, displaying both hada
and water tempered hamon, the stamp indicates it was made with western
style steel instead of the traditional tamahagane.

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: Yes this is true. Old mounts removed and new military mounts as replacements. Reason for this is to make the sword SHOWA. I have several, well more than
messages.messageBody:
Yes this is true. Old mounts removed and new military mounts as replacements. Reason for this is to make the sword SHOWA. I have several, well more than several. Mark Happy collecting.
----- Original Message -----
From: bobgriffis<mailto:bob.griffis@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, July 23, 2006 2:02 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Antique katana blade - showa stamp


Forgive the somewhat newbie question--but, I've read several places
that the presence of a Showa stamp means the blade is circa WWII.
I've also heard that old family katanas were taken to the armory for a
Showa stamp for use during WWII. What is the truth?





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp
messages.msgSnippet: ... I ve never heard of ancestral/antique blades having been given a Showa stamp. All I ve ever heard is that Showa stamps are Showa period made blades; mostly
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "bobgriffis" <bob.griffis@...> wrote:
>
> Forgive the somewhat newbie question--but, I've read several places
> that the presence of a Showa stamp means the blade is circa WWII.
> I've also heard that old family katanas were taken to the armory for a
> Showa stamp for use during WWII. What is the truth?
>

I've never heard of ancestral/antique blades having been
given a Showa stamp. All I've ever heard is that Showa
stamps are Showa period made blades; mostly non-traditionally
made blades.

Rich S

messages.messageBody:
Forgive the somewhat newbie question--but, I've read several places
that the presence of a Showa stamp means the blade is circa WWII.
I've also heard that old family katanas were taken to the armory for a
Showa stamp for use during WWII. What is the truth?
